q:
Bob is using AJAX in his project. Using a basic HTML template, he wanted to display an incoming XML data from file named "data.xml" in form of a table. So he has written the following code.
Code:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>
<table id="inp"></table>

<script>
function loadXMLDoc() {
  var xmlhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();

  //Code

  xmlhttp.open("GET", "data.xml", true);
  xmlhttp.send();
}
function display(xml) {
  var i;
  var xmlDoc = xml.responseXML;
  var table="<tr><th>Names</th><th>Desp</th></tr>";
  var x = xmlDoc.getElementsByTagName("Company");
  for (i = 0; i <x.length; i++) { 
    table += "<tr><td>" +
    x[i].getElementsByTagName("NAME")[0].childNodes[0].nodeValue +
    "</td><td>" +
    x[i].getElementsByTagName("DESCP")[0].childNodes[0].nodeValue +
    "</td></tr>";
  }
  document.getElementById("inp").innerHTML = table;
}

loadXMLDoc()

</script>

</body>
</html>

The display function extracts data from XML file. Now what code should John use in place //Code in the above code, so that the function can display the XML file data as output?

Options:

1

xmlhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
    if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {
      display(this);
    }
  };

2

xmlhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
    addEventListener('readystatechange', event => { })
    onreadystatechange = event => { 
        display();
    }
  };

3

xmlhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
      display(this);
  };

4

xmlhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
      if(xhr.readyState === XMLHttpRequest.DONE) {
            var status = xhr.status;
            if (status === 0 || (status >= 200 && status < 400)) {
                 display(this);
            }
      } 
};
